docs.title: Gecian Hub – Official Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the official documentation of Gecian Hub. This documentation contains everything related to the project, including usage, contribution guidelines, policies, structure, and roadmap.

docs.title: 📌 What is Gecian Hub?
docs.text: Gecian Hub is a student-focused platform designed to help college students access useful resources and participate in beginner-friendly open-source contributions. The goal is to make learning, contributing, and collaboration simple, accessible, and structured.

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text:
This repository may appear to follow a microservices architecture; however, this was not the original design objective.

Each service was developed independently and at different times, with the intention of being hosted and operated individually. The current repository functions as a central hub (Gecian Hub) that brings these services together.

Gecian Hub primarily serves as a showcase, collaboration, and discovery layer, while adjacent or related services maintain their own value, specialization, and autonomy.

docs.title: Repository Structure
docs.text:
• The repository aggregates multiple independently developed services.
  • These services are loosely coupled and designed to function independently.
  • Gecian Hub acts as a coordinator and interface, not as a monolithic application.
  • For future maintenance and security purposes, the frontend of individual services may be integrated into the Gecian Hub, while their backends can be migrated or connected to the Gecian backend without merging everything into a single system. This separation is intentional and exists to support tighter security controls and better isolation.

docs.title: Backend & Frontend Architecture
docs.text:
• Both the frontend and backend are implemented using Next.js.
  • Server-side functionality is handled through Next.js API routes and server components, where appropriate.
  • The system follows a minimal data policy: only data strictly required for functionality is collected and processed.

⚠️ Important The collection or storage of unnecessary user or system data is strictly prohibited. Any violation may result in security, compliance, or operational issues.

docs.title: Storage Strategy
docs.text:
• Indexed storage is used wherever possible to optimize read and write performance.
  • The architecture is designed to operate within free-tier hosting limitations.
  • Storage usage and access patterns are carefully planned to avoid hitting platform-imposed limits.

docs.title: Performance & Cost Optimization
docs.text:
• Client-side load is kept as low as possible.
  • Heavy computation is avoided on the client whenever feasible.
  • Selective caching is applied across both frontend and backend layers to reduce redundant requests and improve performance.
  • Network calls are minimized, and shared resources are reused where appropriate.

docs.title: Key Design Principles
docs.text:
• Modular and loosely coupled services
  • Cost-efficient and free-tier friendly architecture
  • Minimal client payload
  • Indexed and optimized storage
  • Selective and intentional caching
  • Privacy-first and security-conscious data handling

docs.title: 🧱 Technology Stack & Rationale
docs.text: This document outlines the technologies used in the project and the reasoning behind each choice. The stack is intentionally selected to be simple, cost-effective, secure, and suitable for a student-driven, volunteer-based team in 2025.

docs.title: Next.js (Frontend & Backend)
docs.text:
Both the frontend and backend are built using Next.js.

Reasons for choosing Next.js:

  • Simpler development model compared to managing React separately with additional backend frameworks
  • Built-in support for SEO, Server-Side Rendering (SSR), and fast initial load times
  • Widely known and adopted by students and developers in 2025
  • Strong ecosystem with extensive npm package support
  • Unified framework reduces architectural complexity and onboarding time

Using Next.js for both frontend and backend allows the team to maintain a single, consistent technology stack, which is critical for long-term maintainability in a volunteer project.

docs.title: Firebase Authentication
docs.text:
Authentication is handled using Firebase Authentication.

Reasons for choosing Firebase Auth:

  • Free to use within the project’s scope
  • Authentication and security infrastructure is managed by Google
  • Supports multiple authentication methods and additional security factors
  • Eliminates the need to implement and maintain custom authentication logic
  • Reduces risks related to student and user data leakage, which would be a serious concern

Firebase may also be used for limited storage or related services when appropriate.

docs.title: Neon (PostgreSQL)
docs.text:
The project uses Neon as the PostgreSQL database provider.

Reasons for choosing Neon:

  • Generous free-tier offering
  • Fully managed PostgreSQL with modern scaling capabilities
  • Cost-effective for student projects
  • Seamless integration with Next.js and modern JavaScript stacks

This choice aligns with the project’s goal of remaining free-tier friendly while production-ready.

docs.title: Netlify
docs.text:
The application is hosted on Netlify.

Hosting decision background:

  • Initially explored Cloudflare Workers (Node.js runtime)

  • Dropped due to limitations in full Node.js environment support

  • Netlify was selected because:

  • Native integration with GitHub organizations

  • No requirement to fork repositories into personal accounts
  • Simplified CI/CD and deployment workflows

While platforms like Vercel are popular, Netlify better fits the team structure, access control needs, and workflow constraints of this project.

docs.title: End-to-End (E2E) Testing
docs.text:
Playwright is recommended for E2E testing.

Reasons for choosing Playwright:

  • Supports modern browser automation
  • Can generate automation scripts from recorded user interactions
  • Lighter and easier to configure than Selenium
  • Suitable for both functional and UI testing

Alternatives considered:

  • Selenium – Industry standard, but heavy and complex
  • Cypress – Good option, but setup and configuration can be more opinionated

docs.title: Unit & Component Testing
docs.text:
• Jest
  • React Testing Library

These tools are recommended for unit and component testing. Adoption may increase as team familiarity grows.

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text:
CI/CD is implemented using GitHub Actions.

Reasons for choosing GitHub Actions:

  • Native integration with GitHub repositories
  • Centralized automation within the GitHub ecosystem
  • Matches the current skill level of the team

  • Simplifies automation for:

  • Builds

  • Tests
  • Security checks
  • Deployments

docs.title: Google Analytics
docs.text:
The project integrates Google Analytics for usage and traffic analytics.

Reasons for choosing Google Analytics:

  • Free and industry-standard analytics platform
  • Provides real-world usage data (active users, sessions, engagement)
  • Enables contributors to truthfully state analytics-related experience on their resumes
  • Helps the team make data-driven decisions instead of assumptions

Having real production analytics allows contributors to present their experience in a measurable and verifiable format (e.g., “Managed analytics for a production PWA with X monthly users”).

docs.title: Dependency & Vulnerability Management
docs.text: To maintain security without heavy operational overhead, the project integrates:

docs.title: Dependabot
docs.text:
• Automated dependency updates
  • Pull requests for vulnerable packages
  • Native GitHub integration
  • Helps keep dependencies up-to-date with minimal manual effort

docs.title: Snyk
docs.text:
• Scans for vulnerabilities in:

  • npm dependencies

  • Application code
  • Provides clear remediation guidance
  • Acts as an additional security layer beyond Dependabot

These tools help ensure that security issues are identified early, which is critical for a publicly accessible student platform.

docs.title: GitHub-Native Tooling
docs.text:
The project relies entirely on GitHub’s ecosystem:

  • GitHub Issues – Bug tracking and task management
  • GitHub Discussions – Design discussions and community interaction
  • GitHub Projects – Planning, roadmaps, and task boards

Why not Slack, Jira, etc.?

  • This is a college project with volunteer contributors
  • External tools introduce unnecessary complexity
  • Such tools require high discipline and constant engagement
  • GitHub provides sufficient functionality while keeping everything centralized

docs.title: Guiding Principles Behind Technology Choices
docs.text:
• Free-tier friendly
  • Simple onboarding for new student contributors
  • Secure by default
  • Minimal operational overhead
  • Fully GitHub-integrated workflow
  • Practical and sustainable for a volunteer-driven academic project

docs.title: Contributing to Gecian Hub
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to Gecian Hub 🎉 This guide will help you contribute effectively — whether you're a beginner or experienced developer.

docs.title: 🧠 Before You Start
docs.text:
Please make sure you: - Read the README of the repository - Understand the project goal - Follow the Community Guidelines

If you are confused — that’s normal. Ask questions.

docs.title: 🧭 Ways to Contribute
docs.text: You can contribute in many ways:

docs.title: 📝 Documentation
docs.text:
• Fix typos or grammar
  • Improve clarity
  • Add missing sections
  • Write guides or tutorials

docs.title: 💻 Code
docs.text:
• Bug fixes
  • Feature improvements
  • UI/UX enhancements
  • Performance optimizations

docs.title: 🐞 Issues
docs.text:
• Report bugs
  • Suggest improvements
  • Discuss ideas

docs.title: 🎨 Design & UX
docs.text:
• Icons
  • Layout suggestions
  • Accessibility improvements

docs.title: 1️⃣ Fork the Repository
docs.text: Click the Fork button on GitHub.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Clone Your Fork
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/<repo-name>.git
cd <repo-name>
````

---

### 3️⃣ Create a New Branch

Never work directly on `main`.

```bash
git checkout -b feature/short-description

Examples:

  • fix/navbar-bug
  • docs/add-install-guide
  • feature/project-search

docs.title: 4️⃣ Make Your Changes
docs.text:
• Keep changes focused
  • Follow existing code style
  • Add comments if needed

docs.title: 5️⃣ Commit Like a Pro
docs.text:
Use clear and meaningful commit messages:

git commit -m "docs: improve contribution guide clarity"

Format:

type: short description

Examples:

  • fix: resolve crash on login
  • feat: add project collaboration page
  • docs: update README

docs.title: 6️⃣ Push Your Branch
docs.text: git push origin feature/short-description

docs.title: 7️⃣ Open a Pull Request (PR)
docs.text:
When opening a PR:

  • Clearly explain what you changed
  • Explain why you changed it
  • Reference related issues if any

Good PR description:

This PR improves documentation clarity for new contributors by adding examples and fixing grammar.

docs.title: ✅ Pull Request Rules
docs.text:
Your PR should:

  • Be focused (one feature/fix per PR)
  • Not break existing functionality
  • Follow project structure
  • Pass any required checks

Maintainers may:

  • Request changes
  • Suggest improvements
  • Ask questions

This is normal — don’t take it personally.

docs.title: 🧪 Testing (If Applicable)
docs.text:
Before submitting:

  • Test your changes locally
  • Ensure the app builds/runs
  • Check docs formatting

docs.title: 📌 Issue Guidelines
docs.text:
When creating an issue:

  • Use a clear title
  • Describe the problem clearly
  • Add screenshots if possible
  • Mention steps to reproduce (for bugs)

Avoid vague issues like:

“App not working”

docs.title: 🙋 Need Help?
docs.text:
If you’re stuck:

  • Comment on the issue
  • Ask in discussions
  • Reach out to maintainers

Asking questions is encouraged.

docs.title: 🏁 Final Words
docs.text:
You don’t need to be perfect to contribute. You just need to be honest, respectful, and willing to learn.

Every contribution — big or small — matters.

Welcome to Gecian Hub 💙

```

docs.title: 📜 COMMUNITY GUIDELINES
docs.text:
👉 COMMUNITY_GUIDELINES.md or docs/community/community-guidelines.md

# Community Guidelines – Gecian Hub

Welcome to the **Gecian Hub community** 👋  
This document outlines how we work together and what we expect from everyone participating in our GitHub organization.

Gecian Hub exists to help students learn, collaborate, and grow through open source.  
To make that possible, we value **respect, learning, and transparency** over perfection.

---

## 🌱 Our Core Values

### 1. Learning Over Ego
No one here is expected to know everything.
- Beginners are welcome
- Questions are encouraged
- Mistakes are part of learning

There is no place for superiority or gatekeeping.

---

### 2. Respect for Everyone
We respect all contributors regardless of:
- Branch or department
- Experience level
- Background or opinions

Harassment, discrimination, or personal attacks will **not** be tolerated.

---

### 3. Transparency & Honesty
- Decisions should be explained clearly
- Credits should be given fairly
- If something doesn’t work, we talk about it openly

---

### 4. Community Before Code
Code matters — but people matter more.

We prioritize:
- Healthy collaboration
- Constructive feedback
- Long-term sustainability

---

## 🤝 Expected Behavior

We expect all community members to:

- Be polite and respectful in discussions
- Give constructive and kind feedback
- Accept feedback without hostility
- Help others when possible
- Follow repository rules and documentation

---

## 🚫 Unacceptable Behavior

The following will **not** be accepted:

- Harassment or hate speech
- Personal attacks or insults
- Spamming issues or pull requests
- Stealing credit for others’ work
- Forcing changes without discussion

Repeated violations may result in removal from the organization.

---

## 🛠 Maintainers & Decision Making

Maintainers are responsible for:
- Reviewing pull requests
- Managing issues
- Guiding contributors

Final decisions rest with maintainers, but:
- Feedback is always welcome
- Discussions are encouraged
- Decisions should be explained

---

## 🆘 Reporting Issues

If you experience or witness unacceptable behavior:
- Reach out to a maintainer privately
- Or open a confidential issue if applicable

Your concerns will be taken seriously.

---

## ❤️ Final Note

Gecian Hub is built **by students, for students**.  
Be kind, be patient, and help make this a safe place to learn.

Thank you for being part of the community.

docs.title: Why Contribute?
docs.text:
For a normal college student, this is a great chance to get a normal PR (pull request), which can be hard to get accepted in big organizations.

Most projects here are simple and beginner-friendly. If you contribute while you are in college, seniors can directly help you with your contributions.

Working on these projects helps you learn how open-source works. This experience is very useful for programs like GSOC, because many organizations ask for previous open-source contributions.

So, contributing here is an easy way to start open-source, learn step by step, and build your profile.

docs.title: 1. Who can contribute to Gecian Hub?
docs.text:
In general, any student interested in learning and contributing is welcome.

However, some contributions—especially those related to college-specific data, workflows, or internal coordination—may be limited to students of the host college (e.g., GEC SKP) to ensure accuracy, safety, and accountability.

This distinction will always be clearly mentioned in the issue description.

docs.title: 2. Is Gecian Hub restricted only to students of the host college?
docs.text:
No. Gecian Hub follows an open and learning-friendly approach.

  • Open issues → Anyone can contribute
  • College-specific issues → Restricted to host college students

This model ensures both openness and responsible development.

docs.title: 3. Do I need prior experience to contribute?
docs.text:
No prior experience is required.

Gecian Hub is designed as a beginner-friendly project, making it an excellent starting point for:

  • First-time contributors
  • Students new to GitHub
  • Those learning open-source workflows

Guidance and reviews are provided where possible.

docs.title: 4. How difficult are the tasks compared to large open-source projects?
docs.text:
Most tasks in Gecian Hub are significantly simpler than those in large or well-established open-source organizations.

The project is intentionally structured to:

  • Reduce complexity
  • Encourage learning
  • Provide confidence through small wins

It serves as a stepping stone before contributing to larger open-source projects.

docs.title: 5. Are there advanced or restricted issues?
docs.text:
Yes. Some issues may:

  • Require access to internal systems
  • Involve real student data
  • Affect live deployments
  • Need on-campus coordination

Such issues are usually:

  • Marked clearly
  • Assigned to core team members or host college students
  • Not suitable for first-time contributors

docs.title: 6. How will I know which issues I can work on?
docs.text:
Each issue will clearly mention:

  • Skill level (beginner / intermediate)
  • Whether it is open to all contributors
  • Whether it is restricted to host college students

If unsure, always comment on the issue and ask before starting work.

docs.title: 7. Can contributors from other colleges join the core team?
docs.text:
Core team membership generally prioritizes:

  • Availability
  • Long-term commitment
  • Understanding of the host college environment

Students from other colleges may contribute regularly, but core leadership roles are usually reserved for host college students to ensure continuity and accountability.

docs.title: 8. Will contributors receive mentorship or guidance?
docs.text:
Yes, where possible.

  • Maintainers review Pull Requests
  • Feedback is provided constructively
  • Learning is encouraged over perfection

However, contributors are expected to:

  • Read documentation
  • Follow contribution guidelines
  • Respect maintainers’ time

docs.title: 9. What is expected from contributors?
docs.text:
Contributors should:

  • Follow GitHub best practices
  • Communicate respectfully
  • Complete tasks they take responsibility for
  • Avoid submitting incomplete or rushed PRs

Quality matters more than quantity.

docs.title: 10. Can I use my contributions for learning or resumes?
docs.text:
Yes. Contributions to Gecian Hub are:

  • Public
  • Open-source
  • Valid learning experience

You are encouraged to showcase your work responsibly.

docs.title: 1. What is Gecian Hub?
docs.text: Gecian Hub is a student-first platform built to solve real problems faced in daily college life. It focuses on accessibility, simplicity, collaboration, and ethical use of technology to support students across departments and years.

docs.title: 2. Who runs Gecian Hub?
docs.text: Gecian Hub is run by a student core team under a designated Project Lead (Head). Leadership may change over time through a documented succession process to ensure continuity.

docs.title: 3. Is Gecian Hub an official college project?
docs.text: Gecian Hub is a student-led initiative. While it may collaborate with departments or faculty when required, it operates independently unless explicitly stated otherwise.

docs.title: 4. Who can use Gecian Hub?
docs.text:
All students are welcome to use Gecian Hub, regardless of:

  • Department
  • Year of study
  • Technical background

Some features may be limited to verified students to ensure safety and trust.

docs.title: 5. Is Gecian Hub free to use?
docs.text: Yes. Gecian Hub is free for students and is not built for profit.

docs.title: 6. Who can contribute to the project?
docs.text:
Anyone interested in contributing can do so, including:

  • Developers
  • Designers
  • Writers
  • Testers
  • Documentation contributors

Technical knowledge is helpful but not mandatory for all contributions.

docs.title: 7. How do I start contributing?
docs.text:
Start by:

  1. Reading the Contribution Guidelines
  2. Checking open GitHub issues
  3. Commenting on an issue before starting work
  4. Submitting a Pull Request (PR)

All contributions follow open-source best practices.

docs.title: 8. Do I need to be an expert in Git or programming?
docs.text:
No. However, core team members and leads are expected to understand:

  • Creating GitHub issues
  • Working with branches
  • Submitting and reviewing PRs
  • Basic open-source workflows

Beginners are encouraged to learn and grow.

docs.title: 9. How are decisions made?
docs.text:
Decisions are made through:

  • Discussion within the core team
  • Technical review when required
  • Final responsibility resting with the Project Lead

All decisions should prioritize the project’s long-term health and student benefit.

docs.title: 10. Is the platform politically or ideologically affiliated?
docs.text: No. Gecian Hub maintains a politically neutral stance and avoids promoting ideological, religious, or controversial agendas.

docs.title: 11. What kind of content is not allowed?
docs.text:
Content that is:

  • Harmful, offensive, or discriminatory
  • Politically provocative
  • Culturally insensitive or indecent
  • Violates privacy or ethical standards

The platform aims to maintain a safe and respectful environment.

docs.title: 12. How is user data handled?
docs.text:
User data is handled responsibly and minimally. We do not misuse personal data, and access is restricted to authorized maintainers only.

Refer to the Privacy Policy for details.

docs.title: 13. What happens if something breaks or the site goes down?
docs.text:
The project follows a documented Incident Response & Recovery process to:

  • Identify the issue
  • Minimize impact
  • Restore services safely

Lessons learned are documented to prevent repetition.

docs.title: 14. What happens if leadership becomes inactive?
docs.text: If leadership succession fails, the project may be responsibly restarted following the Succession Failure & Project Continuity Protocol, ensuring the original mission continues.

docs.title: 15. How can I contact the team?
docs.text:
• Official communication channels (email, forms, or GitHub)
  • For succession or continuity matters, previous leads may be contacted if necessary

Avoid direct personal messages unless requested.

docs.title: 16. Where can I report issues or suggest features?
docs.text:
• GitHub Issues (preferred)
  • Official feedback forms if available

Clear, constructive reports help the project improve faster.

docs.title: 17. Can this project be forked or reused?
docs.text:
Yes, under the project’s open-source license. However, forks should respect:

  • Ethical guidelines
  • Attribution requirements
  • Community responsibility

docs.title: 🧩 Gecian Hub — Incident & Recovery Handbook
docs.text: A guide for handling system failures, outages, or any critical incidents in Gecian Hub. Designed for contributors and student leads to act quickly and safely.

docs.title: 1. Incident Response Overview
docs.text:
Incidents may include:

  • Deployment failures
  • Database corruption or loss
  • Service downtime
  • Security breaches
  • User-reported functional issues

The primary goal is to restore functionality quickly, protect user data, and document all actions.

docs.title: 2. Incident Assessment & Notification
docs.text:
1. Stay calm. Take note of the exact problem.

  2. Identify affected systems:

  3. Frontend (Next.js / Netlify)

  4. Backend (Next.js API / Neon DB)
  5. Authentication (Firebase)
  6. Analytics / monitoring tools
  7. Notify Leads immediately (Lead, Tech Lead, Outreach Lead) using WhatsApp or GitHub Discussions.

  8. Record basic details:

  9. Date & time

  10. Description
  11. Systems affected
  12. Any immediate actions taken

docs.title: 3.1 Code Rollback
docs.text:
• Revert to the last stable commit in GitHub.
  • Ensure CI/CD pipelines run successfully.
  • Deploy to Netlify with rollback steps if the new deployment fails.

docs.title: 3.2 Database Recovery
docs.text:
• Restore Neon (PostgreSQL) database from the most recent backup.
  • Validate core tables and critical data (users, forms, submissions).

docs.title: 3.3 Frontend / User Cache Issues
docs.text:
• Advise users to clear browser cache or IndexedDB if errors persist.
  • Verify that IndexedDB storage and app installation behavior works as expected.

docs.title: 3.4 Security & Privacy
docs.text:
• Confirm no sensitive data was exposed.
  • Check logs for unusual activity.
  • Ensure dependency updates (Dependabot / Snyk) are applied.

docs.title: 4. Stabilization
docs.text:
1. Pause all new merges or deployments until the system is stable.

  2. Test core functionality:

  3. User login / Firebase Auth

  4. Form submissions and response retrieval
  5. Basic analytics and reporting
  6. Document all steps, fixes, and changes.

docs.title: 5. Communication
docs.text:
• Notify all contributors once the system is stable.
  • Provide a summary of the incident in GitHub Discussions.
  • Note lessons learned and preventive actions.

docs.title: 6. Preventive Measures
docs.text:
• Daily Neon backups
  • Test all changes in staging first
  • Keep dependencies updated with Dependabot / Snyk
  • Follow documented runbooks for rollback & recovery
  • Communicate clearly with leads before taking any critical action

docs.title: 7. Leadership Backup
docs.text:
• If the current Lead / Tech Lead is unavailable:

  • Contact the Mentor / previous Lead (Shadil).

  • Use stored credentials & backup code for emergency deployment.
  • Document all actions for transparency.

⚠️ Note: If succession fails, the next person in line can restart the project locally, host on Netlify, and continue while maintaining continuity.

docs.title: 8. Quick Incident Response Checklist
docs.text:
A condensed version for urgent situations.

  1. Assess & Notify

  2. Identify affected systems

  3. Notify Leads / Mentor

  4. Document

  5. Time, issue, actions taken

  6. Rollback

  7. Code → Revert last stable commit → Deploy

  8. Database → Restore backup

  9. Frontend → Clear cache / IndexedDB

  10. Stabilize

  11. Pause merges

  12. Test core workflows

  13. Notify & Review

  14. Inform contributors / users

  15. Document root cause and lessons

  16. Preventive Measures

  17. Daily backups

  18. Test in staging
  19. Update dependencies

docs.title: 9. Final Notes
docs.text:
• No unnecessary data should be collected or stored.
  • All actions should prioritize user privacy, security, and system integrity.
  • Keep documentation updated for future contributors.
  • Emergency restores are the responsibility of the current Lead / Tech Lead; legal and privacy risks are explicitly their responsibility.

This handbook ensures continuity, safeguards data, and empowers new contributors or leads to handle incidents safely.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This document outlines the procedures to follow when an incident occurs, such as service outages, data corruption, or failed deployments. It also defines the rollback and recovery steps to ensure the platform remains functional and contributors can safely resume work.

The goal is to minimize downtime, protect user data, and maintain trust in a volunteer-run student project.

docs.title: 1. Incident Types
docs.text: Type Description Example Deployment Failure Issues after new code pushes Broken UI, backend API errors Database Issues Corruption, accidental deletion, or schema mismatch Neon database downtime, lost tables Hosting/Infrastructure Problems with Netlify, CI/CD, or server downtime Failed deploy, site not loading Security Incident Unauthorized access, vulnerability exploit Compromised Firebase auth, dependency vulnerability Data Loss IndexedDB corruption or deletion User settings or flags reset Service Misbehavior Bugs causing repeated errors Infinite loading, form submission failures

docs.title: 2. General Response Guidelines
docs.text:
1. Stay Calm and Assess

  2. Identify what happened, when, and how widespread the issue is.

  3. Do not make hasty changes without understanding the problem.

  4. Notify the Core Team

  5. Inform the Lead, Tech Lead, and relevant role owners immediately.

  6. Use GitHub Discussions, email, or WhatsApp channel for communication.

  7. Document Everything

  8. Record time of incident, symptoms, affected systems, and immediate actions.

  9. This documentation is crucial for post-mortem analysis.

  10. Determine Impact Scope

  11. Who or what is affected: users, contributors, or specific services?

  12. Prioritize actions based on severity and urgency.

docs.title: 3. Rollback Strategy
docs.text:
When a deployment or system change causes failure:

  1. Use Git Version Control

  2. Roll back to the last known stable commit in GitHub.

  3. Ensure PR merges are reviewed before re-deploying.

  4. CI/CD Reversion

  5. If using GitHub Actions + Netlify, redeploy previous working version.

  6. Confirm the rollback site functions correctly before notifying users.

  7. Database Rollback

  8. Restore Neon database from the most recent backup.

  9. Only apply rollback if data loss or corruption is detected.

  10. Verify that restoration scripts do not override unrelated production data.

  11. Frontend Storage Recovery

  12. IndexedDB resets may affect client devices.

  13. Users may need to clear cache or reload the app.
  14. Provide clear instructions for affected users.

docs.title: 4. Recovery Steps
docs.text:
1. Stabilize the System

  2. Stop any ongoing changes that may worsen the problem.

  3. Disable non-essential services if necessary to reduce load.

  4. Deploy Stable Version

  5. Use Netlify rollback options or redeploy stable commit from GitHub.

  6. Confirm key workflows (login, form submission, analytics) are functional.

  7. Validate Data Integrity

  8. Ensure Neon database and Firebase authentication remain consistent.

  9. Check logs for errors or anomalies.

  10. Notify Stakeholders

  11. Inform contributors, admins, and potentially users that the incident has been addressed.

  12. Include root cause summary if known.

  13. Document & Review

  14. Complete a post-incident report in GitHub Issues or internal docs.

  15. Identify areas for preventive measures.

docs.title: 5. Preventive Measures
docs.text:
• Frequent Backups

  • Schedule Neon backups at least daily.

  • Store backups in versioned and accessible locations.

  • Test Deployments

  • Use staging branches in GitHub before production merges.

  • Encourage team contributors to review changes carefully.

  • Monitoring & Alerts

  • Use Google Analytics and GitHub logs to detect abnormal behavior.

  • Set alerts for high error rates or failed CI/CD pipelines.

  • Security Updates

  • Dependabot and Snyk must be monitored regularly.

  • Apply patches before deployment to reduce incident risks.

  • Clear Documentation

  • Maintain updated runbooks for all team members.

  • Include step-by-step rollback and recovery instructions.

docs.title: 6. Critical Notes for Contributors
docs.text:
• Responsibility: Each contributor is accountable for their changes. Missteps affecting production are not automatically fixed by maintainers.
  • Communication: Notify Leads immediately if unsure about rollback procedures.
  • Testing: Always test locally or in staging before deploying to production.
  • Succession Awareness: In case the leadership changes, successors must have access to rollback procedures and backups.

docs.title: 👋 Who Am I?
docs.text:
My name is Shadil. I am a B.Tech student at Government Engineering College, Palakkad (GEC SKP).

Unlike many people you might see in tech communities, I don’t consider myself a particularly talented person. I also feel that I did not fully utilize many of the opportunities that were given to me.

For example, if I had made better use of the guidance and time I had with my seniors, I might have grown to a completely different level. This documentation—and this project—comes from that realization.

I am not writing this as a success story, but as an honest one.

docs.title: 🌱 How It Started
docs.text:
Gecian Hub did not start as a main project.

The very first idea was a repository called Gecian Archive.

Around 2024–2025, I asked some of my seniors—Vishnu Sunil and Rithin V, who were also my hostel mates—to review my work. During those conversations, an idea came up:

If there was a place where seniors could showcase their projects, juniors could get inspired and build something more meaningful instead of just completing a mandatory mini project.

This mattered because:

  • Mini projects may be easier for some branches like CSE
  • But for branches like EEE, building meaningful projects is much harder without guidance

With that idea, we started building Gecian Archive as a simple platform to showcase student projects.

At the same time, the FOSS Club also built a similar platform. There was no conflict—I simply shared that I was working on this as well.

docs.title: Not Just for One College
docs.text:
As the project evolved, it became clear that Gecian Archive and related repositories were not official GEC platforms.

They were created under an open-source GitHub organization called CodeCompass, which I later forked and adapted to suit a college ecosystem.

Since GEC is a government institution, using any platform officially would require multiple permissions. My teachers and HOD clearly told me that official adoption would not be possible—and that was completely understandable.

I don’t hate the college for this. I don’t love it either.

I simply don’t take it personally.

docs.title: ❓ Why It Started
docs.text:
If someone asks me in one word how I feel about college, my answer would be: neutral.

I was never deeply involved in college activities. I spent more time in my hostel than in college itself.

The idea behind Gecian Hub was never to fight the system or replace anything. It was born because:

  • There was no internal way for departments to collaborate
  • There was no central place for student-built tools
  • Existing official apps focused on administration, not student creativity

Over time, multiple ideas came together:

  • Gecian Archive
  • Gecian Collaboration
  • Hostel-related tools

Eventually, these ideas merged into what is now called Gecian Hub.

As of now, Gecian Hub jut offical realsed it is not widley adopted yet

That number may or may not grow—and that’s okay.

I am leaving this project to others, and I genuinely hope it succeeds even without me.

docs.title: 🤝 Giving Credit Where It’s Due
docs.text:
I want to clearly state something important.

The following projects:

  • Gecian Archive
  • Gecian Collaboration
  • GEC Hostel-related projects

were originally built by Soorja Krishna.

Later, me, Abhiram, and Abhijith added support and improvements to these projects. They were built inside the CodeCompass organization and later forked as needed.

My role was:

  • Building on top of what already existed
  • Giving ideas
  • Connecting people
  • Structuring things for the community

Gecian Hub, however, was built with collaboration from students of batch 2022–2026, along with a few contributors from 2024–2028.

Special Thanks to Nirjan r , sreehari , Ashin t , hursh g

I am not a special person. I just wanted to give back to my fellow students the same kind of guidance and inspiration my seniors once gave me.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text: Goal: Get everyone to install the Gecian Hub app on their phone and use it regularly.

docs.title: 🌟 Mission Statement
docs.text: Our mission is to empower every student by providing a single, accessible digital hub that simplifies college life, improves efficiency, and bridges the gap between students and essential academic, technical, and community resources. Gecian Hub exists to ensure that no student feels left behind due to lack of information, communication, or technology, regardless of their background or year of study.

docs.title: 🚀 Vision Statement
docs.text: Our vision is to create a connected, tech-enabled student community where every student has equal access to opportunities, resources, and collaboration. We aim to transform traditional college experiences by introducing modern digital solutions, encouraging innovation, and ensuring that no student ever feels their institution is outdated or lacking in technological support.

docs.title: 🌱 Core Values & Principles of Gecian Hub
1. Student-First Design
docs.text: Every feature of Gecian Hub is built with students at the center. We focus on solving real challenges faced in daily college life through practical, intuitive, and reliable solutions.

docs.title: 2. Accessibility & Equal Opportunity
docs.text: We believe every student deserves equal access to information and resources. Gecian Hub is designed to be inclusive and accessible to all students, regardless of department, academic year, or technical background.

docs.title: 3. Simplicity & Efficiency
docs.text: Technology should reduce complexity, not add to it. Our platform emphasizes clean design, minimal steps, and efficient workflows to help students save time and focus on what truly matters.

docs.title: 4. Privacy, Trust & Confidentiality
docs.text: We respect user privacy and handle data responsibly. Personal information is never misused, and features such as anonymous feedback systems are built with transparency, security, and trust as core priorities.

docs.title: 5. Collaboration & Campus Community
docs.text: Gecian Hub encourages collaboration, knowledge-sharing, and interdisciplinary teamwork. We aim to strengthen campus culture by enabling students to connect, support one another, and grow together.

docs.title: 6. Ethical & Responsible Content
docs.text: We are committed to maintaining high ethical standards. The platform does not promote or support content or activities that may be harmful, inappropriate, immoral, or socially irresponsible. All content is expected to contribute positively to personal growth, learning, and character development.

docs.title: 7. Cultural Sensitivity & Respect
docs.text: We respect cultural values, traditions, and social norms of the student community. Content and features are designed to remain appropriate, respectful, and mindful of moral boundaries, avoiding material that may be offensive, indecent, or culturally insensitive.

docs.title: 8. Neutrality & Non-Division
docs.text: Gecian Hub maintains a politically neutral stance. We do not promote political ideologies, controversial agendas, or divisive content that could create conflict, discrimination, or unrest within the campus community.

docs.title: 9. Safe & Dignified Digital Environment
docs.text: We strive to provide a safe, dignified, and respectful digital space. Content that objectifies individuals, promotes indecency, disrespects personal dignity, or undermines social harmony is not tolerated.

docs.title: 10. Academic & Moral Integrity
docs.text: We uphold integrity in all academic and community interactions. Dishonesty, plagiarism, misuse of resources, or unethical behavior is discouraged, ensuring a trustworthy and responsible learning environment.

docs.title: 11. Continuous Improvement
docs.text: We believe in constant growth. Gecian Hub evolves based on student feedback, emerging needs, and responsible innovation to ensure long-term value and relevance.

docs.title: 12. Innovation with Purpose
docs.text: We adopt modern technologies thoughtfully and responsibly. Innovation is driven by real student needs and meaningful impact—not trends—ensuring technology serves a clear and positive purpose.

docs.title: Our Commitment
docs.text: Gecian Hub is committed to fostering a respectful, inclusive, ethical, and student-centered platform that aligns with institutional values and promotes both academic excellence and personal responsibility.

docs.title: 1. General Policy
docs.text:
• Gecian Hub does not store any personal data by default.
  • All user interactions are anonymous unless explicitly required for a feature, which must be approved by the core team.

docs.title: 2. User-Generated Content
docs.text:
• If the project starts allowing user posts or submissions, contributors or leads may need to track certain permissions to avoid misuse.
  • Important: There is no monitoring of users by default, and the project cannot guarantee the behavior of users.

docs.title: 3. Responsibility Disclaimer
docs.text:
• Any feature or process that involves storing data or tracking users is the sole responsibility of the team implementing it.
  • Gecian Hub’s original founders or previous leads are not liable for misuse, breaches, or legal issues arising from user data.

docs.title: 4. Contributor Awareness
docs.text:
All contributors should understand:

  • Do not assume safety or monitoring exists
  • Be careful when enabling features that handle personal or sensitive data
  • Follow ethical standards and college policies if handling user content
  • If unsure, pause and consult the lead before proceeding

docs.title: 5. Legal Disclaimer
docs.text:
• The project is student-run and open-source.
  • Any consequences arising from storing, sharing, or misusing data are the responsibility of the current team implementing those features.
  • Gecian Hub and its founders disclaim any liability for data-related issues caused by contributors, core team, or future leads.

“We do not store data. If you implement a feature that tracks or stores user data, you are fully responsible. codecompass and its founders are not liable.

docs.title: 1. Purpose of the Disclaimer
docs.text:
• Before using Gecian Hub, users must acknowledge a disclaimer.

  • This ensures legal awareness and consent for terms of use, especially regarding:

  • Responsibility for posted content

  • Project limitations
  • Data handling practices

docs.title: 2. How the Disclaimer Works
docs.text:
• The disclaimer triggers once per device/browser.

  • We use IndexedDB in the browser to remember if a user has accepted:

  • If IndexedDB is present, the disclaimer does not trigger again.

  • If IndexedDB is cleared or missing (e.g., new browser/device), the disclaimer will trigger again.

⚠️ This is intentional and recommended by legal counsel.

docs.title: 3. Legal Rationale
docs.text:
• The lawyer advised that a visible acknowledgment should be kept for each user session.
  • IndexedDB provides a lightweight, local-only solution without storing personal data.

  • This ensures:

  • Compliance with legal advice

  • No personal data storage
  • Users are aware of their responsibilities

docs.title: 4. Responsibility Statement
docs.text:
• Gecian Hub does not store personal data.
  • The disclaimer only tracks acknowledgment locally for a device/browser.
  • If a user clears IndexedDB or switches devices, the disclaimer will reappear.

⚠️ Future contributors or leads must not bypass or remove this mechanism, as it is a legal requirement.

docs.title: 5. Contributor Notes
docs.text:
• Contributors implementing new features should:

  • Respect the disclaimer trigger

  • Avoid storing personal information without legal approval

  • Consult the core lead if a feature requires tracking users

  • The project cannot be held liable if a contributor bypasses this disclaimer or misuses user data.

docs.title: Privacy Policy
docs.text:
Gecian Hub has a mandatory Privacy Policy that governs:

  • Minimal data collection
  • User content handling
  • DMCA and content removal
  • Legal disclaimers

This Policy must always be kept intact. It was carefully reviewed and approved following legal advice.

docs.title: Key Points
docs.text:
1. Do Not Remove or Alter

  2. The Privacy Policy is required for legal compliance.

  3. Any attempt to remove it may violate legal guidance and the terms of the project.

  4. IndexedDB Disclaimer Mechanism

  5. The disclaimer trigger relies on IndexedDB to track acknowledgment per device.

  6. This mechanism cannot be bypassed or removed.

  7. Legal counsel advised keeping this for compliance.

  8. Responsibility

  9. Contributors and leads are solely responsible for features that store, track, or handle user data.

  10. Gecian Hub founders or previous leads bear no liability for misuse or legal consequences.

  11. Minimal Data Policy

  12. The platform collects only anonymous logs or voluntarily submitted content.

  13. No passwords, personal credentials, or sensitive data are stored.

docs.title: Actionable Guidance for Contributors & Leads
docs.text:
• Do not delete the Privacy Policy page.
  • Do not bypass or modify the disclaimer trigger.
  • If a new feature requires tracking users or storing content, document it and get approval from the core team.
  • Always remind new contributors about responsibility for user data.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: This document outlines how conflicts should be managed within the Gecian Hub community and Executive Committee (ExCom). The goal is to resolve issues constructively, maintain trust, and keep the project running smoothly.

docs.title: 1. General Principles
docs.text:
1. Respect & Professionalism

  2. All parties must treat each other respectfully, regardless of role or experience.

  3. Personal attacks or harassment are not tolerated.

  4. Transparency

  5. Conflicts should be addressed openly with the relevant parties.

  6. Decisions or resolutions must be documented.

  7. Problem-Focused Approach

  8. Focus on issues, not individuals.

  9. Avoid blame; prioritize solutions over arguments.

  10. Escalation Hierarchy

  11. Conflicts are first handled at the lowest possible level.

  12. Escalate only if resolution is not achieved.

docs.title: 2. Conflict Types
docs.text: Conflict Type Examples Resolution Path Technical Code review disagreements, architecture decisions Tech Lead → Lead if unresolved Design UI/UX disputes, branding inconsistencies Design Lead → Lead if unresolved Community / Outreach Contributor disagreements, recruitment disputes Outreach Lead → Lead if unresolved Operational / Policy Scheduling conflicts, resource allocation Vice Lead → Lead if unresolved Personal / Interpersonal Miscommunication, behavior issues Lead or Mentor involvement if necessary

docs.title: Step 1: Identify the Issue
docs.text:
• Clearly define the problem or disagreement.
  • Focus on facts and impact, not personalities.

docs.title: Step 2: Communicate Privately
docs.text:
• Discuss the issue one-on-one or in small groups.
  • Aim to understand the other party’s perspective.

docs.title: Step 3: Seek Mediation
docs.text:
• If private discussion fails, involve the Lead or Vice Lead.
  • Lead may act as a mediator to propose solutions.

docs.title: Step 4: Document the Resolution
docs.text:
• Record the problem, discussion points, agreed resolution, and next steps.
  • Share documentation with relevant ExCom members.

docs.title: Step 5: Follow-Up
docs.text:
• Check after a reasonable period to ensure the resolution is effective.
  • Adjust the approach if needed.

docs.title: 4. Escalation Policy
docs.text:
1. Minor Issues → Handled by role-specific lead.
  2. Persistent / Major Conflicts → Escalate to Lead.
  3. Unresolvable Conflicts → Mentor (previous Lead) may provide advice, but final authority rests with current Lead.

⚠️ The Mentor is advisory only; they cannot enforce decisions.

docs.title: 5. Contributor / Student Conflicts
docs.text:
• Conflicts involving contributors or students should be handled by Outreach Lead first.
  • If unresolved, escalate to Lead.
  • Document all communications and actions.

docs.title: 6. Preventive Measures
docs.text:
1. Clear Roles & Responsibilities

  2. Follow documented ExCom roles to avoid overlapping authority.

  3. Open Communication Channels

  4. Maintain regular meetings and updates.

  5. Encourage contributors to voice concerns early.

  6. Respect Policies

  7. Always follow Privacy Policy, Legal Guidelines, and Decision-Making process.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: This document explains how decisions are made within the Gecian Hub Executive Committee (ExCom). It ensures clarity, responsibility, and accountability across all roles.

docs.title: 1. General Principles
docs.text:
1. Responsibility follows Role

  2. Each role is responsible for decisions in their area of expertise.

  3. Lead has final responsibility for all decisions.

  4. Consensus First, Authority Later

  5. Whenever possible, decisions should be discussed and agreed upon collectively.

  6. If consensus cannot be reached, the Lead makes the final decision.

  7. Documentation is Key

  8. All important decisions should be recorded in a shared document or issue tracker.

  9. Decisions include rationale, participants, and expected outcomes.

  10. Transparency

  11. Decisions impacting students, contributors, or project direction should be communicated clearly to relevant stakeholders.

docs.title: 2. Role-Based Decision Authority
docs.text:
Role Decision Scope Escalation Lead Overall project direction, priority setting, final approvals None Vice Lead Decisions in Lead’s absence; operational coordination Lead Mentor Advisory only; cannot enforce decisions Lead or Vice Lead Design Lead Design, UI/UX, branding, visual consistency Tech Lead (if technical conflict) or Lead Tech Lead Code quality, architecture, technical approaches, deployments Lead Outreach Lead Community outreach, contributor onboarding, recruitment Lead

⚠️ Roles should not overstep into areas outside their scope unless explicitly delegated.

docs.title: Step 1: Identify the Decision
docs.text: • Define what needs to be decided, urgency, and potential impact.

docs.title: Step 2: Gather Input
docs.text:
• Relevant ExCom members provide input based on their roles.
  • Discuss alternatives, pros/cons, and constraints.

docs.title: Step 3: Propose a Solution
docs.text: • Lead or responsible role proposes a recommended course of action.

docs.title: Step 4: Reach Consensus
docs.text:
• Attempt to agree collectively on the solution.
  • Document any concerns or dissenting opinions.

docs.title: Step 5: Final Decision
docs.text:
• If consensus is reached → decision is implemented.
  • If not → Lead makes the final call, explaining reasoning to the team.

docs.title: 4. Escalation Policy
docs.text:
• Operational Conflicts: Escalate to Lead or Vice Lead.
  • Technical Conflicts: Escalate to Tech Lead, then Lead if unresolved.
  • Design Conflicts: Escalate to Design Lead, then Lead if unresolved.
  • Community/Outreach Conflicts: Escalate to Outreach Lead, then Lead.

In emergencies, the Lead can make unilateral decisions, but must inform the team afterward.

docs.title: 5. Voting & Tie-Breaking
docs.text:
• Decisions that require multiple approvals may be voted on by ExCom members.
  • Lead has tie-breaking authority.

docs.title: 6. Documentation & Communication
docs.text:
1. Record all decisions in shared ExCom docs or GitHub issues.
  2. Note the decision, date, participants, and rationale.
  3. Communicate decisions affecting contributors, users, or external parties.
  4. Revisit decisions if outcomes differ from expectations or new information arises.

docs.title: 7. Review
docs.text:
• ExCom should review key decisions quarterly to ensure alignment with:

  • Project goals

  • Student needs
  • Legal and privacy compliance

docs.title: Suggested Organization Structure (Flexible)
docs.text: There is no fixed structure. You can keep it as simple or as detailed as needed. However, having the following roles is recommended:

docs.title: 1. Lead
docs.text:
• Main person responsible for decisions and direction.
  • Manages the team and overall progress.
  • Final point of responsibility.

docs.title: 2. Vice Lead
docs.text:
• Supports the Lead.
  • Takes over if the Lead is unavailable.
  • Helps coordinate between different roles.

docs.title: 3. Mentor (Last Year’s Lead)
docs.text:
• The previous year’s Lead acts as a Mentor.
  • Contact the Mentor only in urgent situations.
  • The Mentor is not part of official groups or daily operations.
  • Role is advisory only.

docs.title: 4. Design Lead
docs.text:
• Official lead for all website design work.
  • Maintains UI/UX consistency.
  • Reviews design changes before implementation.

docs.title: 5. Tech Lead
docs.text:
• Someone strong in technical skills.

  • Responsible for:

  • Code quality

  • Architecture decisions
  • Technical guidance
  • Helps with deployments and tech-related issues.

docs.title: 6. Outreach Lead
docs.text:
• Handles outreach, communication, and recruitment.

  • Responsible for:

  • Recruiting new students to contribute

  • Growing the student contributor community
  • Communicating opportunities to students

  • Works on:

  • College outreach

  • Contributor onboarding
  • Increasing participation and engagement

Note: This role does not focus on social media management. The main goal is bringing students into the community and helping them start contributing.

docs.title: 1. During Admission Time
docs.text:
• When first-year students arrive for admission, our team or volunteers can be present at the entrance.

  • Politely inform them:

  • If they want to know more about the college website and services

  • They can visit the website
  • They can also install it as an app
  • Keep the explanation short and friendly.

docs.title: 2. After Admissions Are Completed
docs.text:
• During the first or second week, conduct an orientation session:

  • Offline class (preferred, if possible)

  • Online class if offline is not possible

  • In this session:

  • Explain the entire app

  • Show how to use key features
  • Explain how to install the app

docs.title: 3. Target Audience
docs.text:
• The main focus should be first-year students.
  • Most features of the app are especially useful for first years, so they should be the priority audience.

if we repeat this for 4 year by then we may get above 1000 user

docs.title: Future Plans
docs.text: all the idea are embeeded in the github issue the current lead can decide what to focus one

docs.title: Lessons Learned
docs.text:
1. Cloudflare Compatibility

  2. The new Cloudflare app method is not compatible with the Node.js environment. Please keep this limitation in mind during development.

  3. Strict Legal Disclaimer

  4. This is the foundational policy and must not be removed or altered.

  5. Do not engage in or promote anything controversial in the future.
  6. This includes supporting or opposing any political party, political figure, group, or community.
  7. If anyone does anything of this nature, I am not responsible.

  8. This disclaimer has been reviewed with a lawyer and is intentionally strict and airtight.

  9. Posting Restrictions

  10. It is strongly recommended that users do NOT have direct permission to post content on Gecian Hub itself.

  11. This is because we currently do not have full visibility or control over all activities.

  12. Images Usage

  13. For various reasons, it is best to avoid using images as much as possible.

  14. User Tracking (Minimum Requirement)

  15. If users are allowed to post or submit anything, their email ID must be tracked at minimum.

  16. Email Policy

  17. We are not using PKD email IDs.

  18. This decision is made to avoid potential legal issues in the future.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Create a Firebase Project

1. Go to the Firebase Console https://console.firebase.google.com

  3. Enter a project name (e.g. gecian-hub)
  4. Disable Google Analytics (optional)

docs.title: 2️⃣ Get Firebase Client (Public) Configuration
docs.text: These values are used on the frontend (Next.js).

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Firebase Console → Project Settings
  2. Scroll to Your Apps
  3. Click Add App → Web

  5. Copy the generated config

docs.title: Example

const firebaseConfig = {

  projectId: "project-id",
  storageBucket: "project-id.appspot.com",

docs.text:
```js rules_version = '2'; service cloud.firestore { match /databases/{database}/documents {

match /adminemail/{doc} {
  allow read: if request.auth != null;
  allow write: if false;
}

match /{document=**} {
  allow read: if true;

}

} }

docs.title: 1️⃣ Go to Neon Console
docs.text:
1. Open 👉 https://console.neon.tech
  2. Sign in with GitHub / Email
  3. You will land on the Projects dashboard

docs.title: 2️⃣ Create a New Neon Database (Per Repo)
docs.text: Repeat these steps for each repository.

docs.title: Step-by-step
docs.text:
1. Click New Project
  2. Fill details:
Field Value Project name e.g. gecian_project_collab Postgres version Default (recommended) Region Choose closest to users Branch main
  1. Click Create Project

⏳ Neon provisions the database automatically.

docs.title: Recommended Regions
docs.text:
Repo Region India / Asia-facing apps AWS Asia Pacific (Singapore) Global / US-facing apps AWS US East (N. Virginia)

⚠️ Do not mix regions randomly

docs.title: 4️⃣ Get the Database Connection URL
docs.text:
After creation:

  1. Open the Neon project
  2. Go to Dashboard → Connection Details
  3. Copy Connection String

It looks like this:

postgresql://USERNAME:PASSWORD@HOST/DATABASE?sslmode=require

Example:

postgresql://neondb_owner:password@ep-xyz.us-east-1.aws.neon.tech/neondb?sslmode=require

docs.title: 🔹 Backend / Next.js Repo
docs.text:
Inside the repository root:

cp .env.example .env.local

Then edit .env.local:

DATABASE_URL="postgresql://USERNAME:PASSWORD@HOST/DATABASE?sslmode=require"

docs.title: 🔸 student_app_backend
docs.text: DATABASE_URL="postgresql://.../gecian_hub_backend?sslmode=require"

docs.text: DATABASE_URL="postgresql://.../gecian_project_collab?sslmode=require"

docs.text: DATABASE_URL="postgresql://.../gecian_project_showcase?sslmode=require"

docs.title: 🔸 Gec_Hostel
docs.text: DATABASE_URL="postgresql://.../nearbt_hostel?sslmode=require"

docs.title: 8️⃣ Verify Connection Locally
docs.text:
Run:

npm run dev

If DB is connected correctly:

  • No connection errors
  • Migrations run successfully
  • API routes work

docs.title: 9️⃣ Neon Dashboard – What You’ll See
docs.text:
For each database:

  • Name
  • Region
  • Created At
  • Storage
  • Branches
  • Integrations

Example:

gecian_project_collab
Region: AWS Asia Pacific (Singapore)
Branches: 2
Storage: ~31 MB

docs.title: 🔐 Security Rules (MANDATORY)
docs.text:
• ❌ Never commit .env.local
  • ❌ Never reuse DATABASE_URL across repos
  • ✅ Use .env.example for reference
  • ✅ Rotate credentials if leaked

docs.title: 🚀 Gecian Hub – Complete Local Setup (Copy-Paste Ready)
docs.text: This guide sets up all Gecian Hub–related repositories, installs dependencies, and prepares the environment for development.

docs.title: 📋 Prerequisites
docs.text:
Make sure you have:

  • Git
  • Node.js (v18 or later)
  • npm

Verify:

git --version
node -v
npm -v

docs.title: 📁 Step 1: Create Workspace
docs.text:
mkdir gec_skp_dev
cd gec_skp_dev

docs.title: 📦 Step 2: Clone All Repositories
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/GEC-SKP-DEV/gecian_hub.git
git clone https://github.com/GEC-SKP-DEV/gecian_project_collaboration.git
git clone https://github.com/GEC-SKP-DEV/Gec_Hostel.git
git clone https://github.com/GEC-SKP-DEV/gecian_project_archive.git
git clone https://github.com/GEC-SKP-DEV/student_app_backend.git

docs.title: 1️⃣ Gecian Hub (Frontend)
docs.text:
cd gecian_hub
npm install
cd ..

docs.title: 2️⃣ Project Collaboration
docs.text:
cd gecian_project_collaboration
npm install
cd ..

docs.title: 3️⃣ Gec Hostel
docs.text:
cd Gec_Hostel
npm install
cd ..

docs.title: 4️⃣ Project Archive
docs.text:
cd gecian_project_archive
npm install
cd ..

docs.title: 5️⃣ Student App Backend
docs.text:
cd student_app_backend
npm install
cd ..

docs.title: Frontend
docs.text:
cd gecian_hub
npm run dev

Run other services as needed in separate terminals.

docs.title: 🧠 Notes for Contributors
docs.text:
• All repositories are independent
  • Always run npm install after pulling updates
  • Node version should be consistent across repos

docs.title: ✅ Setup Complete
docs.text:
At this point, your local directory should look like:

gec_skp_dev/
├── gecian_hub/
├── gecian_project_collaboration/
├── Gec_Hostel/
├── gecian_project_archive/
└── student_app_backend/

You are now ready to contribute 🎉

docs.title: Using Hacktoberfest for Contributions
docs.text:
Hacktoberfest is a program where we can tag our repositories as Hacktoberfest-ready. This helps us get many free and genuine contributions from the open-source community.

This is also a great opportunity for the executive/core team to:

  • Learn how to use GitHub PRs
  • Review and merge pull requests
  • Understand basic open-source workflows

Since contributors are already motivated, it often results in easy and quick PRs.

If you know of other similar programs, we can also enroll the organization in them to receive more contributions.

⚠️ Important Note: Because this is a college website, this approach should be used only if student contributions are low or inactive. It is a backup strategy, not the primary one.

docs.title: 1. Official Email Access
docs.text:
• Create and hand over the official email ID to the new lead.

  • Make sure they can:

  • Send and receive emails

  • Reset passwords for linked tools
  • Avoid using personal emails for official work.

docs.title: 2. Google Drive & Documents
docs.text:
• Explain the folder structure in Google Drive.

  • Highlight:

  • Important documents

  • Policies, disclaimers, and legal files
  • Past plans and reports
  • Ask the new lead to review Google Drive within one month.

docs.title: 3. Google Forms
docs.text:
• Show all active Google Forms.

  • Explain:

  • Why each form exists

  • Who should access the responses
  • Ensure the new lead checks responses regularly.
  • Transfer ownership of critical forms if needed.

docs.title: 4. GitHub Organization Access
docs.text:
• Give the new lead Owner permission in the GitHub organization.

  • Walk them through:

  • Repository structure

  • Branch rules
  • PR review and merge process
  • Explain who else has admin or maintainer access.

docs.title: 5. Current Programs & Issues
docs.text:
• Brief the new lead on:

  • Ongoing programs (e.g., Hacktoberfest, open-source drives)

  • Recent issues or blockers
  • Any legal, technical, or community-related risks
  • Clearly state what is working and what is not.

docs.title: 6. Current Plan & Vision
docs.text:
• Explain the short-term plan (next 1–3 months).
  • Explain the long-term vision.

  • Share:

  • Pending tasks

  • Deadlines
  • Priorities

docs.title: 7. Advice for the New Lead
docs.text:
• Keep everything documented.
  • Avoid controversial or sensitive activities.
  • Do not give direct posting permission without tracking users.

  • Regularly monitor:

  • GitHub activity

  • Google Forms
  • Official email inbox
  • Google analytics
  • Ask seniors or previous leads if unsure—no guesswork.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: This document defines the process to ensure continuity of the project in the event that leadership succession fails, becomes inactive, or the project setup is disrupted. The goal is to ensure that the project does not die due to mismanagement, negligence, or loss of access, and can continue to benefit students.

docs.title: 🚨 When This Protocol Applies
docs.text:
This protocol applies if any of the following occur:

  • The leadership succession is broken or abandoned
  • The project becomes inactive without formal handover
  • Access to repositories, hosting, or documentation is lost
  • The existing team becomes unresponsive or non-functional
  • The project is at risk of being discontinued despite student interest

docs.title: 🔄 Right to Restart the Project
docs.text:
If you are genuinely interested in continuing this project within your own college and the succession has failed:

  • You are allowed to restart and relaunch the project independently
  • The objective must remain aligned with the original mission: helping students
  • The restart should be done responsibly, transparently, and ethically

This is not a fork for personal gain, but a continuity effort for community benefit.

docs.title: 👤 Original Project Contact (Strongly Recommended)
docs.text:
Before restarting, you should attempt to contact the original initiator:

  • Name: Shadil AM
  • Role: Original Creator / Initiator
  • Preferred Contact: LinkedIn

If reachable:

  • Coordinate to understand the original vision
  • Request guidance, context, or approvals if necessary

docs.title: ❗ If Contact Is Not Possible
docs.text:
If the original initiator cannot be reached:

  • The existing project setup or team may provide access to:

  • Source code

  • Configuration
  • Documentation
  • You may proceed in good faith to relaunch the project

docs.title: 🛠️ Technical Restart Guidelines
docs.text:
• Use the provided or recovered codebase
  • Host the project responsibly (e.g., Netlify or equivalent)

  • Ensure:

  • Clean deployment

  • Secure configurations
  • Proper environment variables
  • Maintain documentation from day one

docs.title: ⚠️ Important Warnings
docs.text:
• Do not repeat mistakes of previous leadership

  • Avoid:

  • Poor documentation

  • Lack of accountability
  • Inactive ownership
  • This project is not casual or experimental
  • It carries responsibility toward current and future students

docs.title: 🤝 Commitment Expectation
docs.text:
Anyone restarting the project must commit to:

  • Long-term maintenance
  • Ethical and responsible usage
  • Respect for community values
  • Transparency in leadership and decision-making

This project exists to serve students, not individual recognition.

docs.title: 🧭 Final Note
docs.text:
The intent of this protocol is simple:

This project must continue, evolve, and help many others — regardless of leadership failure.

If you choose to take responsibility, do it seriously, do it correctly, and do not abandon it halfway.

docs.title: 1. Team Formation Authority
docs.text:
• The newly appointed Head (Project Lead) shall have the authority to select the rest of the core team based on project needs.
  • Team selection must prioritize commitment, reliability, and contribution over popularity or titles.

docs.title: 2. Criteria for Selecting the New Head
docs.text: The current Head shall select the next Head based on the following criteria:

docs.title: a. Technical Competence
docs.text:
• The candidate must have a strong understanding of technology relevant to the project.
  • They should be capable of understanding technical discussions and making informed decisions.

docs.title: b. Team Leadership Ability
docs.text:
• The candidate must be able to motivate, coordinate, and bring others together to work toward a common goal.
  • The ability to encourage participation and resolve conflicts is essential.

docs.title: c. Responsibility & Execution (Most Important)
docs.text:
• The candidate must demonstrate that when responsibility is given, the task is completed.
  • Talent and social skills are valuable, but without responsibility and follow-through, they are meaningless.
  • Consistency and reliability are the most critical qualities for this role.

docs.title: d. Commitment & Availability
docs.text:
• The candidate must be willing to invest time and effort regularly.
  • Leadership requires presence, follow-ups, and accountability.

docs.title: e. Communication Skills
docs.text:
• The candidate should be able to communicate clearly and respectfully with team members, advisors, and administrators.
  • Both technical and non-technical communication are important.

docs.title: f. Problem-Solving Mindset
docs.text:
• The candidate should remain calm during challenges and focus on solutions rather than blame.
  • The ability to make decisions under pressure is essential.

docs.title: g. Integrity & Fairness
docs.text:
• The candidate must act with honesty, transparency, and fairness.
  • Decisions should always be made in the best interest of the project, not personal preferences.

docs.title: h. Willingness to Learn
docs.text: • The candidate does not need to know everything but must be open to learning, feedback, and guidance from seniors and advisors.

docs.title: 🧭 Final Principle
docs.text:
A good leader is not defined by popularity or talent alone, but by responsibility, consistency, and the ability to get work done through people.
